page.title: 05Ecology of Caerhun Parish
page.content: The climate is moderate, prevailing winds south-westerly. Winter conditions can be harsh. Streams drain the hills to River Conwy and reservoirs. The terrain is mainly grassy grazing land with rocky outcrops and wetland. There are many tracks, dry-stone walls and ditches. There are scattered trees on high ground, in the valleys are small woodlands of rowan, sycamore, alder, birch, holly, oak, ash. Plants: on high ground _ spagnum moss, various grasses, heather, harebell, creeping cinquefoil, hawkweed, clover, tormentil, bilberry, lichens and gorse; on low ground _ meadowsweet, foxglove, yarrow, bracken, wild rose. Birds: kestrel, skylark, jackdaw, wheatear, blackbird, meadow pippit. Mammals: rabbits, hares, wild ponies, foxes, sheep and cattle.
